review_title: Excellent intellectual challenges, miserable social atmosphere
pros: Plenty of opportunity to conduct serious, deeply technical research. Students and grad students intelligent and most are eager to learn. Teamwork is valued in the classroom. Entrepreneurial professors have good track record of substantial grants and industry contracts. Good athletic and computing facilities. Region is great for outdoor activities, especially if you like hiking, cold weather and snow!
cons: RPI has mostly analytical, quantitatively-inclined community members. This encourages conversations at all levels to be more intense and confrontational than need be. Women faculty do not have a "critical mass" and so tend to retreat into their work and look out for themselves rather than be able to relax and really develop a network. Most faculty live far away from campus, so there is little after-hours chance for students to visit with faculty families. LGBT life is very tough on this campus and in the surrounding towns. RPI is pretty much the antithesis of a liberal arts college!

review_title: It seems that Lighting Research Center had seen its best days, and are living in the past
pros:
* The facilities at the center are good in comparison to many other research laboratories
* In theory at least, the center is involved in many areas of lighting 
* Location is conveniently in downtown Troy (if you happen to like Troy)
* Overall, the staff is generally pleasant, and there is good and friendly atmosphere
cons:
* Management is not in practice open to ideas from outside their comfort zone and what they are used to. This seems to be partly a result of majority of the people being educated at the center, and continuing to work there after getting their degrees. The communication with outside researchers and the whole scientific community seem to be minimal, and no new fresh ideas are inputted to their process.
* There is a clear lack of long-term planning, and most of the projects seem to be done with the idea of pleasing their funders in short-term leaving the projects kinda patchy while neglecting the investments for research infrastructure needed to stay on top or ahead of the game.
* The center does not seem to be integrated well with the Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute, and there seems to be some political game going on with the Institute and the Center. And it is strange to have two competing lighting centers (Smart Lighting Center) within the same Institute.
* 
* High turnover of dissatisfied employees
* Troy as a place is not the most exciting

pros:
Great compensation; some free time for research (assuming you have figured out teaching); supportive management.

This is a great position if you graduate from RPI with a PhD and find it difficult to find a job. If your end goal is academia, you get valuable teaching experience. You have no boss and you can allocate your time as you need. Compensation is best-in-class for any non-tenure-track positions anywhere. Summers are paid without any workload. If you choose to teach in summer, you may get up to 11,000$ for every course you teach! Usually its competitive but very much possible to get one course, difficult to get two. The Deans are very supportive of your future career and will happily write you recommendation letters and give you flexibility to leave the position when you find your next job. Just don't leave middle of the semester!!

RPI will match 8% for 1% of your retirement contribution!!
cons: no potential for any promotions / tenure-track. Don't be mistaken - this is a 'post-doc' type job. There is no future potential to go to TT in RPI.  Time for research is limited to weekends. But if you have figured out your teaching, or are teaching courses you have taught previously, there is a LOT more time.

review_title: The only thing in supply is criticisms
pros: The benefits were mostly ok. Medical was great but expensive most you paid was the copay everything else gets washed away. My coworker was amazing keep going and trying to get out of the place. Paid time off was good but they forced you to use almost a week during the time between Christmas and New Years. If you are accomplished and reached the pinnacle of your career and are fine with below average money come to RPI. Everyone else look elsewhere.
cons: Management didn’t care at all or recognize your contributions and always tried to give you a 2% raise every year. I got a living wage job offer and they counter offered a lot less than the other companies job offer and tried to pass it off that theirs was better. They have money somewhere but they don’t want to give it to their staff to acknowledge their existence. A lot of the people there had no common sense and wanted you to continue working for garbage money. The president is one of the top earning heads of universities in the nation, but she doesn’t pay any of her staff a decent wage.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in East Greenbush, NY
pros: Work with great people.  Retirement plan match is excellent 8% on 1% contribution.  Medical is affordable.
cons: Raises are pretty much non-existent.  1% on average.  2% is considered a great year.  Heard that this year will be 0.3%.  Paid time off  (PTO) is pathetic when you are new.  First year you get 18 days, however the institute is closed the week of Christmas and they make you use your PTO days during that time which is 4-5 days.  That leaves you with potentially 13 days for the year.  This is all inclusive of vacation, sick and personal time.  It's not nearly enough for anyone with a family.  Human Resources is a joke.  They are not responsive to the employees needs/suggestions.  They take forever to post a job when someone leaves.  They seem to be a pawn for the president.

pros: Tuition benefits are good if you have kids or time and are interested. My direct colleagues are caring and passionate people who make the job better. Decent benefits.
cons: Never in my decade+ of experience know higher desiccation have I ever been so micromanaged and disrespected. I've been told to stay in my place and I constantly  have to check- in with my boss. And I keep answering the same questions over and over. Administration can't seem to manage themselves so I have to provide the same updates to the same people on multiple occasions. I wonder how anything gets done - probably because the people in entry and mid level roles make it happen. We hand hold our students to the point where I feel like a parent and we constantly overreach. Everything is an emergency and when admin says jump you do it while asking how high. I've been there less than a year and I'm fatigued and frustrated and job searching. I could not recommend any of my friends working in my division or in my job.

pros: There's plenty of motivated people doing great things.   For the most part, the research projects at the school are very inclusionary. I've found professors to always be open to discussion in their offices and via email regarding potential opportunities and even just for general conversation. To boot, the compensation for undergrads is very reasonable , we have the ability to take pay or credit (getting graded credit is very worth it IMO, especially with the inherent grade deflation at RPI & credit cost)
cons: There's somewhat of a veil and barrier to entry on how to actually get involved in all of the experiences and opportunities at Rensselaer. At orientation the official channels for research are advertised (online portal) but in actuality, I and my many of my peers have found more opportunities by networking and staying vigilant for unofficially posted on campus opportunities (flyers/rumors/reddit).

pros: Met many professors who are devoted to teaching from maths and computer science. Many interesting courses in maths and comp sci.
cons:
As an MANE graduate student, I don't find enough interesting courses being taught in our department, which is a shame.

The equipments in the gym are really really old. There is only one equipment for ab training. Once it was broken for one whole semester and no one took care of it! C'mon, we are rated top 10 for our tuitions!

The computers in research labs / centers are heavily out of date and no one even thinks about replacing them. I can't believe I have a intel Pentium series desktop in my office when I just came here.

Some old school profs still use the projector and transparent tape for lecture notes. I don't find any students like them.

review_title: Just a few changes and it could be great.
pros: The tuition benefit is the strongest asset for employees of RPI and their families.  The people and culture are also excellent.  The campus is beautiful and the college is cutting edge and reputable.
cons: THEY SELDON PROMOTE FROM WITHIN.  Even if you have excellent qualifications for a position (B.S. or B.A. or a higher degree and a proven track record) it is difficult to obtain higher positions because they seem to always find someone with direct experience; or one of their new graduates who is allowed to trump you. I was underemployed the entire time I was there, but the tuition benefit kept me there.  Also, twice in the last five years there were no raises and they also reduced the tuition benefit significantly.

review_title: PhD at the School of Engineering
job_title: PhD Graduate Student in Troy, NY
pros: Lots of facilities and collaboration opportunities, at RPI and in the surrounding area. The experience is dependent on the department and advisor. Though there is flexibility to have multiple advisors, you need to have significant motivation to get your work done on your own.
cons: Graduate school paper work is a little opaque, you need to have a good department administrator to help navigate it if you want to do anything "creative" with your program, like taking a semester off, changing departments, or advisors, without loosing funding eligibility.

review_title: Benefits/Salary Make it Tolerable (for a while)
pros:
Location - Troy is an outstanding place to work and Rensselaer has done a great job re-purposing older buildings in the city for use as office space.

HR - it's a solid team that really tries to support their employee base (although the employee development program shouldn't be designed to charge employees for skill development/training). Benefits are reasonable and salary was fair.
cons:
Management - At the highest levels of administration the attrition was outrageous for a college that aspires to be nationally known - especially in Advancement/Student Affairs. It's controlling, petty, and demeaning to staff (Finance Dept as an example). Very little recognition is available and advancement is limited.

Resources - very little (aside from the aforementioned buildings) is invested in infrastructure.  Systems are outdated and staff are constantly tasked 'to do more with less' to the point where it's easier to leave.

review_title: The research facilities were superb, but the pay was not.
pros: They are focused on growing their research enterprise, and investing in heavily in facilities to achieve that growth.  Access to research equipment is quite broad.  The president has a clear vision for the future of the institute.
cons: President Jackson is a polarizing figure, which can provide a substantial distraction on campus.  While the institute is investing heavily into its biotechnology, computing and experimental media facilities, many of the more traditional engineering departments (which still account for a large portion of enrollment) are feeling passed over.

pros:
Best  research instrumentation in the capital region, for those of us who like to play with expensive toys.
People are nice to each other: pleasant work environment. Schedules are flexible, which is a must if you have children. Excellent health plans for employees, reasonable retirement benefits are also a plus.
cons: The campus is in the middle of impoverished section of Troy, so there are some personal safety issues. Emphasis is slowly shifting from engineering toward performing arts and other "cool" programs, with budget priorities following the trend. The salaries are not competitive and raises are not even close to compensating for the inflation, provided a raise is given. One of the lamest management decisions was to massively lay off people a week before Christmas 2008 due to the economy crisis.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Troy, NY
pros: A lot of flexibility for research methods with some of the best professors and faculty in the country.  My experience with the Center of Automation Technologies and Systems (CATS) has excellently positioned me for competitive positions at the top of my area (Robotics)
cons: The administration at the highest level can be somewhat frustrating to work with as the budget for new faculty seems to be dwindling.  Note that as a graduate student you are always expected to produce regardless of time invested.

review_title: Worked as a work study student throughout my years as an undergrad at RPI. Overall, it was a good experience.
pros: Since I was a work study student, it was important that my job wouldn't interfere with my studies, which it didn't. Very flexible, sometimes I had a work study gig that I could just do homework at, other times I actually just did work for the department I was assigned to. At one of the departments, I learned some valuable skills that I was able to apply to my classes.
cons: Not many cons I can think of, I guess you might not be able to get the department you want, so you end up working somewhere that won't add anything special to your experience. Some of the work can be extremely boring.

pros: Rensselaer has very bright students who can be very inspiring to work with. The campus is beautiful and the people are friendly. Professional and career development are encouraged.
cons: There is a distinct hierarchy at Rensselaer and it's a bit top heavy in administration. Morale is affected by the perception of mixed up priorities. A lot of money goes into new buildings and temporary dressing to impress board members and visitors while older buildings lack refurbishment and repair. The president has the persona of a "very important person" instead of being in touch with faculty, students and staff.

review_title: Pay is not the best, and you work hard.
pros: It is worth being at RPI, because the research is great. There are great projects in terahertz and particle physics - including Daya Bay and Jefferson Laboratory. You will walk away with a great degree, if you have the stamina to finish!
cons: It can be very tiring working here. The work demand is very high, and the pay is not very good. It can be stressful, and sometimes there is so much work, there is no time to sleep!

review_title: Hire more professors who commercialize research
pros: Great research environment, very nerdy but focused on world changing issues. Needs more risk appetite among the students, financial support and bigger prizes for things like Change the World challenge from institution would help.
cons: Only downside is the lack of a big city environment around here. And the winter.

pros: Opportunity for self-development; Strong engineering research; Good connection with industry; Closeness to G.E. and some other big companies; Good environment suitable for life
cons: The location of this institute is not good enough. It is at least three hours from nearby big cities and there are not many other academic institutes. the educational fees keep raising very rapidly here and even more expensive than IVY league. Some top researchers are leaving this place.

review_title: All around good university, but overpriced outside of Engineering department
pros: RPI has a great reputation for its engineering school and has a relatively lively geek culture complete with several yearly conventions and hundreds of nerdy clubs and activities
cons: Most of the programs outside of the engineering and business schools are only average or slightly above average quality, but they're priced the same as the prestigious programs. The business school is quite good, but still priced higher than comparable programs.

pros: Good retirement benefits, academic environment and campus community helped keep me there. There were a few excellent colleagues but they all left as soon as another opportunity presented themselves.
cons: Embarrassing administration. An atmosphere that encourages a lack of transparency. No buy in from staff. No upward mobility. People leave and the workload is redistributed among those who stay, until they are forced to leave as well. Everyone is doing the job of two, three people. Turnover is so high and management doesn't seem to mind.

pros: Allows Flexible work Schedule, Ability to Work From Home on various projects,  Supportive Team Environment,  Family Oriented, Professional Learning and Development Atmosphere, Generous Tuition Benefit Package, Research University on the Cutting Edge of Science, Technology, and Engineering
cons: inconsistent classification of Information Technology Positions across the Enterprise,  Poorly Defined Career Path or No Career Path for majority of IT Positions, Monetary Incentives are not keeping pace with Cost of Living increases, Excessive Layers of  Management

review_title: One of the best schools out there to study and work in, particularly materials science department.
job_title: Graduate Student, Post Doctorate in Troy, NY
pros: Extremely helpful and knowledgeable faculties, very friendly environment, not much politics, reputable department, Lots of funding opportunities, very good resources etc.
cons: electron microscopy lab needs an upgrade, Troy while a lovely city in my opinion specially if you live in downtown, but can be small and boring sometimes

review_title: I've learned so much about my school, how things work and and have met all the people I work with as a club leader.
job_title: Student Union Administrative Assistant in Troy, NY
pros: You meet everyone you need to who deals with student life, you get very well connected, you can tune your office skills, they are very flexible with hours.
cons: There are many students working so you do not get a lot of hours, the office is only open during the work day, so students sometimes have problems scheduling because of classes.

review_title: Pretty great place for research and scholarly pursuits.
pros:
+ Great people with sharp, clever minds. I've just started in on random chats with strangers that turn into great conversations. 
+ Good research environment. Link up with faculty or a center you're passionate about, and you'll be set. 
+ Excellent undergraduate education. Graduate classes are excellent too, so long as they're being offered during a semester (check YACS). 
+ Terrific surroundings for activities. Rock climbing, big hills/small mountains for biking, surrounded by killer skiing (less than 2 hours to Killington, Okemo, etc.). There are also literally hundreds of clubs students can get involved with for any activity. Climbing not your thing? How about Smash Brothers Club? (seriously). 
+ Cool options for other R&R nearby. The downtown actually has some great bars, restaurants, and shops if you bother to look. Albany and Saratoga also close at hand with awesome spots.
cons:
- Institute politics can be a sideshow... especially since the Empress Has No Clothes. This might really impact some career staff (or Deans of Engineering?), but grad students and researchers likely won't be as affected. 
- Fun hoops to jump through for ordering/reimbursements/travel, etc. Pretty similar to other research institutions, but you have to stay on top of new policy changes. 
- It does get snowy. You should know this if you're looking anywhere in the Northeast. Not really that bad for many people. 
- Smaller city/area. Again, this is likely personal preference as to whether much of a con or not. 3 hours to NY, Boston, or Montreal if you want to get away.

pros: Professors are usually very friendly and understanding, very easy to work with. Since most classes tend to be small, (this is a private school with total students ~7000), the work load is very reasonable most of the time.
cons: Occasionally some professors/lecturers could be very pushing, and gives you a lot of work load. But this happened only  in one semester. Salary is barely above the minimum for these positions nation wide, which obviously hasn't kept in pace with the inflation rate of rent and other living expenses. Good thing is the tanking oil price helps to compensate some of this.

review_title: Beware of new job posting for Asst Career Dir - Lally School
pros: You will have an opportunity to help a lot of students in this position.
cons: The Director of the Lally School Career Office lacks skill and knowledge in the area of general human relations, management, an MBA career services.

review_title: As a student employee, I found my coworkers and supervisors to be positive and lax.
job_title: Bartender At Clubhouse Pub in Troy, NY
pros: The pay was decent, some jobs allowed for doing homework while on shift, and there was plenty of free food to go around. Working with student peers is a great way to meet people
cons: The administration rarely listened to what we as students had to say. They frequently harped on the mantra that students were high turnover and expendable, while they as full-time employees would be here for much longer than us (and thus their opinions were more important).

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Troy, NY
pros: Worked as a PhD research assistant. Stipend is OK given Troy is such a small city. It is an academic environment so it is quite different from ordinary company. Colleagues are brilliant and funding hasn't been an issue for me. Though I can't say I can research on whatever I want, but I have learned a lot during the process. The campus is beautiful all across the year.
cons: Most buildings are old. My office doesn't have a window. RPI locates in a small city which doesn't suit me. The safety on campus is OK, but not in downtown area.

review_title: Great place to get an education; bad place to work
pros: Best reason to work at Rensselaer is the retirement benefit.  You contribute 1% of salary; employer contributes 8%; vested after 3 years.
cons: Rensselaer treats staff as second-class citizens.  Of course students are deemed as important, as it should be at a university. Faculty are routinely heralded by senior administration, though, unless they are "constellation" research faculty that bring in big money via grants, faculty opinions and needs are largely ignored.  Staff is underpaid, under-appreciated, and under-resourced.  The human resource department provides some professional development and training opportunities for staff that are often well-done and well-received.  However, the general feeling, and my personal experience, is that HR is there ONLY to protect the Institute.  There is no one, no department, no advocate, to protect or stand up for the staff.  When disputes arise between a staff member and a his/her supervisor, involvement with HR will always end with a negative result for the staff member.  In addition, promotions have become nearly impossible to achieve.  Deans and vice presidents have lost the power to promote their own staff.  HR controls promotions under the guise of reviewing/writing properly worded Position Management Tools, a process that is painfully slow and detailed.  Annual pay raises for staff members are usually between 2 and 3 percent.  In recent years this not only lags behind a cost of living raise, but with the poor salaries that staff members are paid, it doesn't even keep up with the additional cost of putting gas in your car.  Also pay raises are merit-based, so you are not guaranteed the 2-3%; if your performance is not at the top of the range, you will get a smaller percentage.  It is not unheard of to get less than 1%.

review_title: Residence Life staff were amazingly dedicated and supportive; administration was detached and unresponsive.
pros:
+Student staff are guaranteed a private room to live in on campus
+Professional and student staff were among the most passionate and hardest-working people I have ever met
+Student staff are allowed to be largely autonomous in fulfilling their job requirements
+Work is rewarding. 
+Student staff are exposed to lots of different campus leaders and departments; networking opportunities are plentiful
+Professional staff were responsive and frequently reached out to student staff on specific ongoing issues and personal self-care
+The students who join Residence Life are among the most active, involved, and positive people on a campus that can sometimes feel exhaustingly negative
+Job performance evaluation is done using a points-based system of positive feedback which always felt fair and constructive.
cons:
-Compensation is incredibly low: free room and a small (think less than $400 for the entire year for RAs) stipend that doesn't even cover books for a semester. Comparable positions at other schools are far better compensated for far less responsibility. 
-Training is appropriately intense but lacks specificity and depth in certain presentations. Topics like diversity and practical skills like self defense, CPR, and first aid are not properly covered.
-Teambuilder activities take up far too much time. They are essential for breaking the ice at the start but wasting 15 minutes at the start of every large staff meeting over the course of the year on them is unnecessary and wastes precious time.
-Hours can be long and/or unusual.
-Resident Directors often only have a mere year of prior experience in Residence Life; this can lead to leadership and intra-staff issues consistent with an inexperienced student leader.
-RAs,LAs,and RDs are required to buy an expensive, potentially unnecessary mealplan

review_title: Weekly Paycheck, good place to learn basics.
pros:
Stores are paid weekly and so are you. This is good for starting out or if you partner is paid biweekly.
You will learn a great deal at this job and the environment is fast paced
cons:
Pay increases are nearly laughable with the scale they lay out.
You will learn a great deal by covering for others who do not pull weight.
Very top heavy in Upper management with many Directors and SVPs who manage only one person.
The standard lunch is to leave, grab food, and work at the desk. Weekends are spent catching up on work.

review_title: I have to pick a title for this?
pros: Well-known institution that can provide good experience!  Professors are knowledgeable, tend to be fairly understanding in terms of employment goes, and do have some exciting projects!
cons: Areas of research are limited, due to RPI being a "smaller" school.  A lot of mechanical areas that are researched are computational in nature, not design oriented.

pros:
Made some great friends working there.

Employers (NOTE: Not administration tier) were jovial and very helpful in the training process.
cons:
Common consensus that administration does not care for both the students and the staff. 

Constantly losing core staff and instead of hiring new staff, the duties are just divvied up among the remaining workers.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Troy, NY
pros: I am graduate student at Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute. RPI is strong in engineering. Students are devoted to their studies and definitely not a party school.
cons: This school is very small and has a good reputation in industry, typically in the northeastern area. But you may never hear it in California... The town it locates does not have many places to go for fun.

pros: Very reputable University with nice perks and benefits. Some staff are very educated, others in lower divisions  are not.
cons: Lack professionalism in hiring process. The interview process took over 4 months with month in-between for any communication. Emails and phone calls for inquires to decision making process was not returned. Be prepared to wait a long time.  Due to the length, left to take a nother job that was in the pipeline.

review_title: I'm amazed at how much I've learned since arriving here.
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Troy, NY
pros: As one would expect at a top engineering school, I've learned a tremendous amount and had the opportunity to work with a lot of very smart people.
cons: Must pay out of pocket for health insurance.  While I have been fortunate, in most cases funding must be renewed each year, leading to uncertainty at times.  Conference travel expenses are only supported partially by the school, which means a lot of out of pocket costs for conferences that aren't within driving distance.

pros:
Prominent, rising engineering school
Management invest a lot of time and money back into the school
Very good technical education that will boost skills in any technical area
Decent campus
cons:
Lack of emphasis on social connections
Faculty interaction is limited and outreach is not established

review_title: “Old boys club” culture with minimal resources for success.
pros: Beautiful campus, friendly colleagues, competitive salaries, good reputation (for now)
cons: Poor leadership, lack of resources, poor communication, toxic environment, lack of trust for administration, zero accountability for poor performers, as people retire their positions are left unfilled leading to other employees performing the duties of multiple positions.

pros: The community within the Institute is solid. As a majority, faculty, staff and students feel welcome to interact with each other on a business and/or when appropriate, a social level.
cons: The continued budget restrictions have reduced the staffing necessary to provide an effective environment for moving forward and maintaining our reputation as a leader in research and education.

review_title: Great Colleagues & Students but Disastrous Senior Management
pros: Brilliant Colleagues, Bright Students, and Great Resources
cons: Below inflation rate raises unless employed at the very top.  Misguided capital spending - EMPAC & presidential palace in particular - will burden future generations with negative ROI that must be recouped with higher tuition thus placing Rensselaer at a competitive disadvantage.

review_title: Well-connected with industry, rapidly improving its stature and connections in top academia
pros: Excellent work facilities, principal investigators and student body. Minimum distractions given Troy is not the biggest of towns. Good alumni network for future opportunities.
cons: Given it is the oldest technical school in the US, it has a long long way to go to be counted in the same breath as the top institutions in the country. Needs to still improve the quality of its graduate students and postdocs who will actually engage in cutting-edge research.

review_title: Great and hard working staff and faculty, upper management and administration are clueless
pros: the staff and faculty are stellar, troy grows on you. amazing architecture. close to boston, nyc, montreal. cheap housing costs overall.
cons: no real way for advancement, constantly asked to do more and more (i'm covering three positions), top down administration who don't listen to anyone but themselves or VP level. HR makes hiring impossible. archaic purchasing policies make doing business very difficult, but the rules dont' apply to upper administration.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Troy, NY
pros:
Great school. Stellar resources for scientific computing research. 

Grad student stipend is considerably higher than other colleges in the NY Capital Region area.

Troy, NY is also rapidly developing with lots of cool new hip businesses to enjoy.
cons:
Grad student stipend still lags behind other top research institutions nationwide.

The school's endowment is way smaller than it should be. The leadership doesn't seem to manage its finances very well. However this does not negatively impact the funding available to researchers in popular STEM disciplines.

pros: Return on investment is very high, RPI is very helpful with finding jobs for graduating seniors. The degree from RPI holds a lot of merit in industry.
cons: It is extremely rigorous and the grading is very hard. There is not very much time for outside activities because the course load is very intense.

review_title: Great experience if planning a graduate degree.
pros: Gave lots of experience working in a lab and teaches you how to write lab reports. Very flexible hours, great chances for networking.
cons: Projects can be very unguided with little or no help when a problem arises. Also, some work can be very monotonous.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Troy, NY
pros: Good school with very little distractions from outside of campus. Campus is beautiful. One of the best I have seen. Professors care about the students and the direction of the school.
cons: dwindling number of professors and course options. Troy is not that exciting and rather a little unsafe at times and places. While professors care and point out concerns, deans of the schools often ignore you.

pros: excellent colleagues and challenges, bright students and valued research focus.
cons: The faculty are more overloaded with teaching responsibilities than comparable institutions, yet research expectations remain very high - this is fine, but in this model, there should be an adjustment to salary to match with comparable business, since RPI is run like a business, it's salary structure should be to.

pros: The environment is relax, cost of living is low, campus is nice, looks like an ivy league school, nice view of  Hudson River and downtown Troy
cons: It really depends on witch professor you are working for. Some of them are very nice but some of them change your life to a nightmare

job_title: Postdoctoral Research Associate in Troy, NY
pros: postodoc position gives flexibility to choose projects (depending on your advisor). troy is a nice place - close to boston, nyc, adirondacks (need a car though), but winters are long and cold.
cons: the pay of a postdoc sucks, but you gain valuable experience in mentoring graduate students and writing proposals and grants.

review_title: No respect for staff, faculty or students
pros:
equitable pay
Troy is beautiful city
Academic atmosphere
cons:
Administration has no respect for the rights or views of students
The work dress code is draconic for women (many departments tell women they have to wear skirts not dress pants in non academic offices).
If you say anything negative about a new administration plan or spending you will be fired.

review_title: Good place to learn, but projects can be needlessly difficult
pros: Very interesting work, motivated and supportive leaders, and you learn something new every single day (of you do your job right)
cons: Projects can be quite poorly planned and you need a good amount of intrinsic motivation to get through the red tape and problems with the general administration staff

pros: People are really nice there. A lot of work to do and it is enough to keep you busy. You sort all the application materials.
cons: You can not use phone while working. A little bit boring when sorting all the application. Just repeat everything day and day.

job_title: Computer Science Mentor in Troy, NY
pros: Incredible CS program. Surrounded by incredibly smart people learning really cool stuff. Opportunities to work on just about anything you want to.
cons: Really week humanities courses, awful administration. Classes can overrun your free time. Many professors are definitely hear to research and not to lecture. CS Department is criminally underfunded.

review_title: Good undergrad, still working on graduate program
pros: One of the best undergrad programs outside of the ivy league.  Good corporate partners.  Interesting physics and computer science grad work.
cons: Shrinking research budgets esp. in Aero engineering, high tuition cost.  Only Miki Amitay's research lab will appeal to an aerospace engineer grad student.

pros: I'm doing my Ph.D. degree here as well as doing jobs such as Teaching Assistant (TA), or Research Assistant (RA). I get compensation, and I'll get my Ph.D.
cons: Low compensation for a TA or RA, no medical insurance coverage, pay activity fees that are not quite related to me,

review_title: Good place to work, new facilities and cool research
job_title: Postdoctoral Research Associate in Troy, NY
pros: The CBIS building has some really cool research going on. Access to some state-of the art instrument. Ample space, even post-doc grad students can have their desk in an office
cons: Due to its location, it lacks accessiblity to other high level research facilities. Slow ordering process

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Troy, NY
pros:
Lots of very smart people
Excellent faculty
Lots of individual student attention
cons:
WORST CITY ON THE PLANET
Terrible weather
Facilities are generally old and small

This school just does not provide the college experience that other large universities can provide.  It is simply a poor choice for an undergraduate education.  Much more appropriate for a graduate education.

review_title: Program Manager responsible for recruitment of new students
pros: Working with the students, staff and faculty made this a great job. The campus is beautiful and improvements to the physical plant are always positive.
cons: Great benefits; other companies make changes to the benefits however Rensselaer provides an affordable benefits package. Annual benefits fair was a great opportunity to connect.

review_title: Really good place to work. Why not change the world?
job_title: Lead Student Systems Administrator in Troy, NY
pros: You get to have a really good team environment and you can learn while you work. Hours are extremely flexible like any other student job.
cons: The Administration can be very top down in how the make decisions and there appears to be limited opportunity to give feedback. At the same time, lower level people aren’t impacted too much.

review_title: It is an excellent place to work.
pros: It pays well. Life at Rensselaer is comfortable and cheap. You get to learn a lot at job because of excellent professors with whom you work.
cons: Troy as a place is really dull. there is not much you can do other than hangout at Rensselaer union.

review_title: I have done work as an undergraduate research assistant in the Energy and Combustion Systems Laboratory
job_title: Undergraduate Research Assistant in Troy, NY
pros: You are able to discuss the amount of work and working times with your professor. The best benefit is that as a student, it is possible to have really flexible working hours
cons: You have to be enrolled at the institute as a student and the fixed pay is $10/Hour

pros: A campus with long history and great faculty. A good place to learn engineering and science. Mechanical engineering and electrical engineering are good.
cons: Tuition keeps rising for many years, and makes it hard for faculties to support students. Research is getting tougher now.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Troy, NY
pros: Solid research, lots of smart people here. Learning the knowledge and skills to obtain a good position after graduation.
cons: Staff is at times unreliable; we're paid for 20 hours of work but expected to put in over 40 hours...but such is the PhD life

review_title: As a student employee I found my coworkers and supervisors to be positive and lax.
pros: Decent pay. High expectation for work standard . High value of school reputation. Plenty of opportunities to learn and improve.
cons: Supervisors sometimes not quite accessible, as some professors of some departments are adjunct. Staff not familiar with other campus resources, even if it's such a small one.

job_title: Grad Research Assistant in Troy, NY
pros: Very nice plan to learn. One of the most beautiful places on the plante.
cons: Bad weather. Salary not that good as in major cities. But the costs are also low compared with major cities.

review_title: To perform research related activities at the graduate level.
pros: Rensselaer is a highly dynamic, research based institution which offers a wide variety of career prospects in different fields.
cons: The city environment is very dull and basically consists of the school as the only hang-out place.

pros: Nice professors, outstanding sudents, great for undergraduate and graduate study, would recommend for applying.
cons: The tuition is expensve, and students are required to live on campus for the first two years as an undergrad, and purchase meal plans, but after that, you are free.

review_title: Good place to work, smart students, and interesting interdisciplinary collaborations
pros: Well-known engineering school, active research groups and projects, close to big metropolitan areas like NYC and Boston
cons: City of Troy is slightly small, you may not like winter, it is a polytechnic school, so the concentration is on engineering and science

review_title: Great place with a lot of brilliant minds to collaborate. Grad life is relaxed and satisfying.
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Troy, NY
pros: Lot of top researchers in almost all frontiers of science and engineering. Melting pot of diverse students. Lot of scope for collaborative research. Good chances for internship and co-op opportunities.
cons: Some courses could be tough and challenging. The winter weather could be harsh, lookout!

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Milford, CT
pros: Good for graduate students.
cons: People ask why RPI is so backward...but what they should be asking is why there are so many backward people at RPI. RPI continues to use triples to manage dorms like a profit center, as a result, I will never, ever, ever, donate anything to RPI as an alumni.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Troy, NY
pros: Opportunity to work on state-of-the-art research.  Friendly professors and staff.  Small enough department that many people know you on a first-name basis.
cons: Some resources are dated, such as the cleanroom.  I often have connectivity issues with WiFi in the mechanical engineering building, which shouldn't be an issue at a tech school.

job_title: Accounts Payable Specialist in Troy, NY
pros: Benefits pay hours enviroment location
cons:
training on new programs is almost non existant.  When reviewed was given an unreasonable amount of f
time to retrain and get up to speed...and I am not s slow learner

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in New York, NY
pros: You get to work among very intelligent people in research and development.  In that sense, it's a once in a life-time opportunity. The location is also nice where it's neither too rural or too urban.
